summary: This is an email chain among Assistant United States Attorneys (AUSAs) from the Southern District of New York (SDNY) discussing scheduling a call to discuss a FOIA case related to Jeffrey Epstein. The emails reference a recent oral argument before Judge Engelmayer, who expressed skepticism about the government's FOIA withholdings under Exemption 7(A) and ordered an in camera review. The court also directed the AUSAs to consult with Audrey (likely a supervisor) and consider conferring with Main Justice.

persons.name: Audrey
persons.role: Supervisor/Attorney (likely at SDNY or Main Justice)
persons.context: Mentioned as someone the court wants the AUSAs to consult with regarding the FOIA case and the possibility of conferring with Main Justice. She is also a potential participant in a scheduled call.

persons.name: Judge Engelmayer
persons.context: Presided over the oral argument in the Epstein FOIA case. He expressed skepticism about the breadth of the government's Exemption 7(A) withholdings and ordered the withheld documents be produced for in camera review.

connections.description: Judge Engelmayer directed the AUSAs to communicate with Audrey and have her evaluate the FOIA case, including potential consultation with Main Justice.

events.title: Oral Argument in Epstein FOIA Case
events.description: A roughly two-hour oral argument was held before Judge Engelmayer regarding FOIA requests related to Jeffrey Epstein. The court was skeptical of the government's broad Exemption 7(A) withholdings.

events.title: Expected Court Order for In Camera Review
events.description: Judge Engelmayer is expected to issue an order directing the government to produce withheld documents for the court's in camera review and to specifically mark materials withheld in connection with the Tortaglione case.

keyFacts: In April 2021, a federal judge (Engelmayer) was highly skeptical of the DOJ's broad use of Exemption 7(A) to withhold documents in a FOIA case related to Jeffrey Epstein.

The court ordered an in camera review of the withheld documents and required the government to specify which withholdings were related to the 'Tortaglione' case versus the broader 'Noel' criminal case.
The court directed the AUSAs to consult with a supervisor (Audrey) and consider whether to confer with Main Justice, noting the recent change in administration might be relevant to the FOIA response.
The email chain shows internal DOJ coordination and scheduling to discuss the court's adverse ruling and next steps in the FOIA litigation.
